Sorry, but this sounds like just more of the usual internet hype. I don't know why I, or most everyone, needs the internet to be faster. Already, I click on a link and within seconds the page I am gong to is fully there. If a page now loads in 3 seconds but a "faster" internet loads the page in 1 second how is my life better? Movies, TV shows and music already stream perfectly, too.

My suggestion is to slow everything down. Not the internet, it's fine the way it is. Just the constant cultural hype of faster, faster, faster. Try slower. You'll feel better.

There has been an ongoing discussion of a "bubble" at myriad local events where inventors, entrepreneurs, angel investors and venture capitalists meet.

There's big difference between the dot com era when many companies went public with zero revenue, and the current era when there are revenues but the IPO has absurdly high P/E ratios.

Nonetheless the novelty factor of social networking wears thins while uses for mobile apps for productivity, healthcare, communications and a million other things increases, limited only by our imaginations.

In the long run it is literally our ability to imagine new ways to invent technologies that provide lasting value that isn't limited. This is a very exciting place to be at this time.

I'm sure there's no single culprit that is solely responsible for our high-inequality / low-growth problem. However, I'm convinced that the gradual "flattening" of the tax code since 1980 has a lot to do with it. The magnitude of the inequality gap is too big be explained merely by the super-rich paying less in taxes, of course, but I think there's also been a huge impact due to the indirect effect that the tax code has on compensation incentives. In the decades following WWII, the ratio of average CEO compensation to average worker compensation was in the neighborhood of 20-to-30. Now it's more like 400. Without a point of diminishing returns on upper-level incomes, there is nothing to keep them from consuming an ever-expanding proportion of our economic growth.

Where I work, all the employees were forced to take a 2% pay cut in the form of a mandatory furlough program. At the same time, the company president took a nice $50 million bonus (well-deserved, no doubt; I'm sure cutting everyone else's pay is back-breaking, soul-crushing work). If the top marginal tax rate was still 90%, there would be little incentive for such gross misallocation of corporate payroll budgets.

Meanwhile, because middle class incomes are gradually declining, there is a consequent decrease in aggregate demand for goods and services, leading to lackluster economic growth.

"There is long standing, reliable research on brain development/attachment styles/developmental stages in children"

Yes, there is, but it doesn't say what you think it does. There isn't a scientific study showing that 6 months is the age at which every child achieves a certain degree or type of "brain maturity" (whatever that means - scientifically, I don't think it means much) that allows "self-soothing." Your theories about internalizing the external soothing object are just that, theories. Maybe they apply to some children, but children are individuals, and blanket theories about how or why they sleep, how or why they cry, and how or why they relate a certain way to the parent, are not useful.

The biggest source of voter suppression today is, as it has been for decades, self suppression. No amount of registration efforts will overtake the laziness of fully half of Americans in this regard. Fail to solve this and you don't win.

I enthusiastically supported Barack Obama in 2008, campaigning for him, contributing to his campaign, and voting for him with pride. Four years later, my enthusiasm has dimmed considerably, and I'm neither campaigning for the President nor donating funds to his re-election. But that doesn't mean that I no longer care. I will be casting my vote for Obama, and am contributing to the Democratic Congressional and Senatorial Campaign Committee. In my case at least, less enthusiasm for the President and the election doesn't mean no enthusiasm.

I also continue to be deeply concerned about voter suppression-- the experience of Ohio voters in 2004 comes sharply to mind. I hope that a future column will discuss organizations that will be registering voters for the 2012 elections, so that those of us who care about voter participation can support this important cause. I am more than happy to donate to voter registration efforts in 2012.

AIDS, and the HIV virus, more than any other social issue or disease, show how uniquely is the American transition from fear and hysterical panic to smug indifference, two extremes which in their own way, distract from winning the fight.

AIDS appears in the American consciousness once a year, at the time of the world conference, when the media reviews the progress on preventions and vaccines, often without reminding communities and individuals of the shifting center of the diseased population or how people can protect themselves and prevent its spread. In many communities, HIV-AIDS has no local face,

Yet we all know it does. Especially in the South, where the epicenter of new AIDS infections, the largest growing cohort, are young, low income black males, many in rural communities. The general conversation seldom targets this specific or acknowledges the rapid and dramatic shift in geography, income, and race of those infected. A local face looks back and holds us accountable to help prevent others from becoming infected.

And those local faces need funds and new strategies.

@Dave Scott: To amplify on your point, Obama never had the rubber-stamp Congress that his predecessor enjoyed during his first term, especially after 9/11. This has to do with both the process, notably the filibuster rules in the Senate, and the nature of the two parties. While there are few remaining moderate, and even fewer liberal, Republicans, the Democrats are more diverse -- with a small fraction being traditional liberals, a larger group being conservative-leaning and the majority centrist. A Democratic president doesn't necessarily have a majority, even when his party has the most members in the House or fewer than 60 Senators.

This has thwarted much of the program upon which Obama campaigned, and has necessitated excessive compromise from his specific policy initiatives (i.e. stimulus, AHCA). Unless re-elected, Obama has to temper aggression in lieu of practical political considerations. A second term, backed by a strong voter mandate and/or the requisite level of majority in Congress, would give Obama a greater opportunity for success.

The phenomenon is stereotype threat - when someone who is a member of a group is about to do something that can be seen as reinforcing a negative stereotype about that group, they hold back. The Republicans have neutralized the Democrats by giving all of their tradtional strengths negative connotations, and so they are reluctant to act. Obama can't call out the GOP for racism, because that would be playing the race card. Democrats are afraid to call for government action to end the economic collapse because that would be calling for big government.

And the more Democrats are afraid to do what needs to be done, the more disenchanted the country becomes with them. It's a self-reinforcing feedback loop.

“Democrats are significantly less likely now (39 percent) than they were in the summers of 2004 and 2008 to say they are ‘more enthusiastic about voting than usual’ in the coming presidential election.”

They do detest Romney and the rule of big money and gaming the voting system.

Unfortunately, they are also very disappointed in what Obama has produced so far. Yes, he is better than McCain would have been, and he is better than Romney would be. But they are so awful that still leaves much room for disappointment.

They don't favor the opponent, they just find their enthusiasm sapped.

The problem is that Obama tried to compromise with the Republicans. He couldn't, because they wouldn't. As president, he owns the result.

In retrospect, he had no choice but to call them out, confront them, and have a political brawl. We all know the reasons not to go that way, but they fail in the face of Republican intransigence.

Obama must now convince voters he has some effective way to call out the Republicans, or voters will simply not feel any enthusiasm for four more years of Republicans behaving badly and running over Obama.
